channel.title: Support - Kicksecure Forums
channel.description: Topics in the 'Support' category User support for the Kicksecure operating system.

item.title: Unplugging external drive doesn't trigger a shutdown
item.dc:creator: NTH9R6
item.description:
Hello Kicksecure folks,

I installed Debian on my brand new Western Digital external SSD drive. Then I proceeded to distro morph it following the guide (prob should have went with the ISO route) and everything works as intended.

However when I unplug my SSD or it comes unplugged somehow (has happened before) it doesn’t trigger a full shutdown?

Why doesn’t it fully shutdown when unplugged?
I do want to add that also set up LUKS when I installed Debian.

Do I need to create a udev rule that runs a shutdown script (unmount, cryptsetup luksClose, and sync)?

3 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Unplugging external drive doesn't trigger a shutdown

item.title: Add SearXNG and Startpage buttons to kicksecure-welcome-page
item.dc:creator: rico
item.description:
Hello. I really like the idea of kicksecure-welcome-page. It’s very convenient to have buttons for different search engines. I think it would be excellent for convenience and privacy if you add the SearXNG search engine in the new update - according to many ratings, for example, https://searchengine.party, it is the most private and secure search engine. And it provides good search results. And you can also add the popular search engine Startpage, which can hide users’ IP.
Thank you for your work

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: Add SearXNG and Startpage buttons to kicksecure-welcome-page

I downloaded the Kicksecure ISO file, and flashed it to a USB drive using Balena Etcher. I then installed the file to a second USB drive using the Calamares installer.
I boot up the second USB drive and get a message that says, “Please enter passphrase for disk rootfs”. How do I fix that problem? Thank you.

item.title: How to use zulucrypt in USER Session?
item.dc:creator: linuxer
item.description:
Hello. How to use zulucrypt in USER mode / USER live mode? I received an important encrypted secret steganographic container in messenger, but I could not open it due to sudo restrictions. I need to reboot, decrypt file, and then load again in USER mode / live mode to respond to interlocutor. This will be inconvenient (this can be a confidential important conversation where time is crucial - for example, if it is related to investigative journalism). What would you recommend in this case? Installing zulucrypt in Podman or Distrobox?

ps Live mode SYSMAINT is very good for viewing encrypted containers and do not save secret session to disk, when you are not limited by time

5 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic
item.source: How to use zulucrypt in USER Session?

item.title: LIVE mode SYSMAINT
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Patrick, does it make sense to limit live mode for increased isolation in user-sysmaint-split, given that disk writing is limited? Live mode is very convenient for testing packages, new programs before installing in PERSISTENT mode. Often I try to install some program, but during installation, I encounter dependency problems, library version issues… as a result, package either doesn’t work or can disappoint me. And then it is very convenient to reboot. Rather than deleting everything I just installed + no traces of such experiments are left on disk

7 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic
item.source: LIVE mode SYSMAINT

item.title: Why passwordless sudo by default?
item.dc:creator: Penthouse
item.description:
I tried Kicksecure for the first time. I found that the terminal gave me sudo su (superuser) access without even asking for a password. A very simple privilege escalation hat lets me access the LUKS password from system memory. WTF? I wanted to try Kicksecure because I saw that it would eventually become Whonix-Host. Is this is a bug?

7 posts - 4 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Why passwordless sudo by default?

item.title: Kicksecure vs Qubes (Whonix)
item.dc:creator: dreaml3zz
item.description:
You can use Qubes OS the secure OS together with Whonix (anonymity). You can use Kicksecure the security by default OS with Whonix too through VirtualBox.

How should an user who is looking for security and anonymity decide between those operating systems?

The main advantage of Qubes OS is its isolated design. In combination with Whonix you have a gateway which enforces all traffic from all VMs going through Tor.

But you might use Kicksecure as your OS exclusively to start your VirtualBox instance and use Whonix from there for all your work or offline VMs. Kicksecure OS updates would go through Tor by default.

What are the drawbacks in such a setup for using Kicksecure compared with Qubes OS?

8 posts - 4 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Kicksecure vs Qubes (Whonix)

item.title: [SOLVED] Are Optical Drives disabled in KS?
item.dc:creator: obtrustive
item.description:
I morphed my Debian into Kicksecure on an old Macbook. Before, the optical drive worked fine, now it’s not recognized at all (“eject” and “lsblk” don’t list it).
My understanding is that the kernel KS uses is the same as Debian, but I also found that some kernel drivers a blocklisted for security reasons (such as firewire because it would enable known exploits).
The problem is that I rely on the optical drive. Is there any way to enable it?

Edit: I found this: /etc/modprobe.d/30_security-misc_disable.conf
Any idea which one is needed for and Apple MacBook2,1 SuperDrive?

SOLVED: by commenting out these lines:
blacklist cdrom
blacklist sr_mod

in:
/etc/modprobe.d/30_security-misc_blacklist.conf

EDIT:
Also had to allow the udf filesystem.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: [SOLVED] Are Optical Drives disabled in KS?

item.source: Sudo update-grub disable live mode! Timeshift does not restore!

item.title: Add VMs in /90overlay-root/overlay-mount.sh
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Hello. in 90overlay-root creates /live/image file system for live mode

#!/bin/sh

# make a read-only nfsroot writeable by using overlayfs
# the nfsroot is already mounted to $NEWROOT
# add the parameter rootovl to the kernel, to activate this feature

. /lib/dracut-lib.sh

if ! getargbool 0 rootovl ; then
    return
fi

modprobe overlay

# a little bit tuning
mount -o remount,nolock,noatime $NEWROOT

# Move root
# --move does not always work. Google >mount move "wrong fs"< for
#     details
mkdir -p /live/image
mount --bind $NEWROOT /live/image
umount $NEWROOT

# Create tmpfs
mkdir /cow
mount -n -t tmpfs -o mode=0755 tmpfs /cow
mkdir /cow/work /cow/rw

# Merge both to new Filesystem
mount -t overlay -o noatime,lowerdir=/live/image,upperdir=/cow/rw,workdir=/cow/work,default_permissions overlay $NEWROOT

# Let filesystems survive pivot
mkdir -p $NEWROOT/live/cow
mkdir -p $NEWROOT/live/image
mount --bind /cow/rw $NEWROOT/live/cow
umount /cow
mount --bind /live/image $NEWROOT/live/image
umount /live/image

is it possible to add a mount and launch virtual disk /var/lib/libvirt/images/debian.qcow2 (file itself is in /live/image) that it is launched in flows without consumption of additional memory? it will make a kicksecure a fantastically secure system (much cooler than qubes). live mode is perfectly launched by live-ISO, but how to avoid a load on memory with an already installed system, as is done with podman containers? solving this problem of memory load will help strengthen anti-forensicism. I use live mode every day, but even 32g of memory is not enough for working with VMs

4 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Add VMs in /90overlay-root/overlay-mount.sh

item.title: Hello, thank you, and a question about Secure Boot
item.dc:creator: spirit_of_solitude
item.description:
Hello lovely gentlemen, before I get going here I want to say a huge THANK YOU for selflessly automating so many good ideas in one place.

I’ve been unceremoniously digging into your wiki and general documentation, beginning (of course!) with a paradigm of Self Help

I’m in the process of migrating from GRUB to Systemd-Boot (formerly Gummiboot) and while the port has gone well, the kernel flag:

efi=disable_early_pci_dma

Works in GRUB, but prevents booting in systemd-boot. Before I go blaming Mr. Poettering for his crimes against humanity (I jest) I wonder if the very intelligent people in this community - with years more experience in this platform than I - may have any thoughts on why this might be.

Thank you very much for any insight, time, or just your thoughts.

PS: If you have any thoughts on UKI (Unified Kernel Images) and TPM bindings, I think I have a working layout but if perhaps there are gotchas to consider, or - and this is my greater fear - by switchinig out GRUB I may remove some hardening you have provided, I would certainly like to maintain all of that, and I would love a heads-up if I have wandered into a security minefield in my experimentations. Thanks.

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Hello, thank you, and a question about Secure Boot

item.title: Cannot upgrade-nonroot
item.dc:creator: Banebere
item.description:
So fresh install on VM, type in the command and this is what i get:

Certificate verification failed: The certificate is NOT trusted. The revocation or OCSP data are old and have been superseded. Could not handshake: Error in the certificate verification. [IP: 127.0.0.1 9050]
Reading package lists… Done
E: Failed to fetch tor+https://deb.kicksecure.com/dists/bookworm/InRelease Certificate verification failed: The certificate is NOT trusted. The revocation or OCSP data are old and have been superseded. Could not handshake: Error in the certificate verification. [IP: 127.0.0.1 9050]
E: Some index files failed to download. They have been ignored, or old ones used instead.
zsh: exit 100 upgrade-nonroot

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic

item.title: Problem with sdwdate
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Hello. I have some problems with sdwdate

● sdwdate.service - Secure Distributed Web Date
Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/sdwdate.service; enabled; preset: enabled)
Active: activating (auto-restart) (Result: core-dump) since Thu 2025-02-27; 3s ago
Invocation: 6242d938293f4a918c975dbc10cce343
Docs: sdwdate: Secure Distributed Web Date
Process: 9338 ExecStart=/usr/libexec/sdwdate/sdwdate (code=dumped, signal=SYS)
Main PID: 9338 (code=dumped, signal=SYS)
Mem peak: 2.1M
CPU: 39ms

  • set -e
  • true ‘INFO /usr/bin/sdwdate-log-viewer: START’
  • /bin/journalctl --boot --output cat -n 10000 -f _SYSTEMD_UNIT=qubes-sync-time.service + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=qubes-sync-time.timer + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=timesanitycheck.service + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=bootclockrandomization.service + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=sdwdate.service + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=whonix-firewall.service + SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER=suspend-pre + SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER=suspend-post + SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER=anondate + _AUDIT_TYPE_NAME=SECCOMP
    Within minimum time ‘Tue Nov 5 00:00:00 UTC 2024’ and expiration timestamp ‘Tue May 17 10:00:00 UTC 2033’, ok.
    Boot Clock Randomization
    Boot Clock Randomization - Kicksecure
  • 104 185583560
    Changed time from … (1740642543.533538103)
    to … (1740642647.205970400).

5 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic

item.title: Current Kicksecure Bullseye repo lacks hardened-malloc packages?
item.dc:creator: PrivacyTux
item.description:
Hello,

I wanted to update a VM that has not been updated for a while.
Unfortunately, the hardened-malloc package is no longer offered. Is there a reason for this and can the package be offered again via the Kicksecure Bullseye repo?

The hardened-malloc package is currently not available in any Bullseye repo, not in Stable, Stable Proposed, Testers, nor in Developers.

Last available version was:
hardened-malloc (0:12.5-1) unstable
Thu, 18 Jan 2024 14:09:29 +0000

Best regards

4 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Current Kicksecure Bullseye repo lacks hardened-malloc packages?

item.title: How to delete command line history?
item.dc:creator: viandi
item.description:
Hi All, I’m new here and still learning Kicksecure. On other Linux distros, if I want to delete my command line history, I can use history -c && history -w. These command options seem to be missing from Kicksecure. What is the Kickescure way to do this? If anyone has a link about how Kicksecure handles the history command, I would be happy to read it. There are probably security and privacy concerns around the history command, so I could see why Kicksecure wouldn’t use the Linux defaults for it. Any help is greatly appreciated!

3 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: How to delete command line history?

item.title: Why doesn't Thunderbird go through Tor by default?
item.dc:creator: Ashwagandha
item.description:
I think Thunderbird should go through Tor just like APT. While Kicksecure and Whonix both serve different design goals/purposes, I think other applications in Kicksecure should take advantage of using Tor by default like APT already is.

These “Apps” should be Kicksecure specific since if the same configuration were on the same Apps on Whonix WS it would cause issues like Tor over Tor or not working etc.

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Why doesn't Thunderbird go through Tor by default?

address: 10.152.152.12 Netmask:255.255.192.0 Gateway: 10.152.152.10 DNS: 10.152.152.10
And it works just fine, however when i do the same in a kicksecure VM…crickets.
What am i doing wrong my duck search didnt provide any workarounds.

4 posts - 3 participants

item.title: Is it possible to download and sync monero's blockchain on usb with persistence?
item.dc:creator: Banebare
item.description:
I want to follow this tutorial:
monero (dot) how/tutorial-how-to-speed-up-initial-blockchain-sync
So i can download the blockchain over clearnet and import it into a monero client running on whonix VM and sync it there

However due to the fact that i want the kicksecure to be on a flashdrive i dont know how this should work.
Should I try to download the blockchain on a hard drive then copy it on a flashdrive and copy it on the kicksecure flashdrive running in persistence mode?

Or would it possible to run the kicksecure flash in persistence, download the blockchain there, copy it into the whoniX VM and then sync it?

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Is it possible to download and sync monero's blockchain on usb with persistence?

item.title: Prevent specific packages from being installed?
item.dc:creator: Ashwagandha
item.description:
Is there anyway to prevent or “blacklist” certain packages from being installed?
I tried creating a preferences file /etc/apt/preferences.d/pkg-blacklist to set pin priority to prevent packages from being installed.

Package: rsh-client
Pin: release *
Pin-Priority: -1

Package: geoclue-2.0
Pin: release *
Pin-Priority: -1

However I believe that if a package has these as a dependency it will still install them, is that true?

If not them could something similar to this be utilized to Kicksecure to block certain packages from being installed that could be problematic to security and privacy?

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Prevent specific packages from being installed?

item.title: Adding grub-live to ubuntu host
item.dc:creator: rico
item.description:
Hi guys. I am using Kicksecure on a virtual machine. Host is ubuntu. I really like ubuntu. in the documentation you say Kicksecure used to work on ubuntu, but you chose debian because of potential problems with canonical. in the documentation you say grub-live can work on ubuntu /wiki/Grub-live#Compatibility, but I tried installing it on ubuntu, mint 22 and kubuntu and grub menu item does not appear. please help me what I should change in code to make it work on ubuntu. I would like to be able to run live mode for the whole system. this could be an additional defense for those using Kicksecure on an ubuntu host. thank you

11 posts - 4 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Adding grub-live to ubuntu host

item.title: upgrade-nonroot privilege escalation issue?
item.dc:creator: newcool
item.description:
https://xcancel.com/ProudmuslimDev/status/1878163686365544823#m

upgrade-nonroot
gives me the option to open a root shell with no auth required

Privilege escalation on Kicksecure, a step-by-step guide:

  1. Start a system update as the default user
  2. If a config file modified by the sysadmin has been updated by the pkg maintainer, select “open root shell to inspect the problem”*
  3. Congrats

10 posts - 5 participants

Read full topic
item.source: upgrade-nonroot privilege escalation issue?
